item.content:
Introduction and disclaimer

Right from the start, for legal reasons this story is entirely made up and all possible hints to real or legal entities are completely fictional.

With that out of the way…

How did we get here?

Well, to begin this story I should mention that I’ve had an apprenticeship for around 2 years, during which we got handed a project involving another company, precisely a steel manufacturer.

As you might be able to imagine, any manufacturer of goods also needs and has a pipeline for the manufacturing process. To give you an easy example, a steel manufacturer can produce bridges and planes. Some parts like screws might be needed in both, but they each still require parts that are specific to them.

So you essentially have a list of materials, which can be converted / made into different materials and so on, until you have a final product or rather products.

Now your task is to optimise the pipeline in such a way, that it accounts for prioritisation of tasks, reducing ultimatively the time spent resulting in lower energy costs, as well as executing processes in the most parallel way.

Ohh yeah and they don’t generally make their profits from standard parts, but custom manufactured ones…

First steps

With all that information, you might think I’d have done a problem analysis, methodically approach a solution, or do literally anything else other than directly working on a simulation with different materials, processes and machines along with the properties for each…

Well, jokes on you. Back then (1 year as of writing) that’s exactly what I did.
